comments.commentBody: A Republican Party that must be made to pay for knowingly nominating and endorsing a psychopath for president.

Check out what happened to California as soon as it ended the rigged redistricting. More diversity of candidates, better representation and as a consequence a flourishing economy.

We will soon find out if the political institutions of the USA are stronger and more durable than a one-man wrecking crew. Other nations (Germany, Venezuela, Chile, Italy) had the misfortune to find out that wasn't the case for them.

And let's not forget: This is a one-man wrecking crew enabled and assisted every step of the way by a discredited Republican Party.

There are many dimensions to this "non-working" prime age male population.

For example, many of the disability cases are work related, the highest disability rates in the country are in coal country in KY, where opioid use is also the highest in the country. The Upper Big Branch mine disaster revealed that almost all dead miners had black lung disease and that air quality safeguards were deliberately bypassed by the company, while Federal Social Security picks up the disability tab.

Another, perhaps the largest contributor is the worker who is paid cash for work and avoids bank accounts in favor of prepaid debit cards. They are motivated to avoid taxes, child support and alimony, all of which can be levied on bank accounts. Only 61% of child support payments are made, but many others pay the custodial parent in cash and kind.

When the Deepwater Horizon disaster trustees attempted to reimburse small businesses along the Gulf Coast for losses, very few actually had any recent tax returns to support their claims because they hadn't filed any.

It's past time to better understand how much of the male labor participation fall-off is really the explosion of the cash economy.

Bill

You are wrong. Millions of people are addicted to prescription pain killers. Oxycontin is highly addictive. The article points out that it is also not very effective at relieving pain. If you would watch Frontline on PBS, you would have learned that overuse of Oxycontin is fueling the heroin epidemic. You would learn that there are pill mills where people line up to get prescriptions all day long for these drugs. Many addicts start with a legitimate use like a sore joint or injury and then quickly get addicted.

Once again, you are making the conservative argument that moral failing causes drug addiction. It does not. I am not making a shameful slur against decent human beings. You are speaking from ignorance stemming from a complete lacking of understanding how drug addiction starts and perpetuates itself.

Yes, these are good decent people who are also drug addicts. They are your neighbors and co-workers. Millions of them, everywhere. Most of them are white. They are dopers just like the people on the street. They have jobs and function, but they are still dopers.

Just because you don't understand something, doesn't mean the something doesn't exist. Good decent working people with prescriptions are drug addicts. Millions of them. And now, many are turning to heroin because its much cheaper. Millions of them.

The pills include aspirin and ibuprofen.   Many functioning people take these frequently.   I wouldn't recommend that because of the potential damage to the stomach and kidneys, but it's hardly a serious problem.
Why do you believe these statistics?

These statistics are frightening. This study claims that 20% of working men between the ages of 25 and 54 are chronic users of pain killers. That means one in five men in their prime at the office, the factory, the warehouse, at the construction site are are taking medications each day to relieve pain. And I thought cigarettes were a pubic health problem!

How on earth can something like this happen? This means tens of millions of pills are being consumed each day for pain. They must be coming from somewhere? Are they coming from the drug cartels or are they coming from neighborhood drug stores? Who is writing all of these prescriptions?

We have seen so many accusations, particularly from the right, that drug use is a moral failing. With drug use of these proportions, that argument goes out the window. These guys have jobs. They aren't bouncing between the street and jail.

A couple of years ago, I asked a contractor working in the neighborhood with a hispanic crew if he tried to hire white guys. He said he really does try but most of them can't pass a drug test. No kidding!

Big pharma is now the pusher de jour. Doctors are now the enablers. The insurance companies are the financiers and the rest of us pay for it all with sky high premiums.

And we wonder why healthcare consumes 18% of GDP. Man what a gravy train. It all starts with that first bottle of pills. And they still have pain.

Very good analysis of the societal mechanics of the legal, pharmaceutical, and the relationship between type of work environments and physical disabilities. As you've pointed out, the complexity of getting just one person straightened out in the sense of treatments for the physical, emotional, and mental issues in combination with the legal (compensation or other issues) ageisim limits and discrimination, plus whatever re-training is possible is maddening and there will be many ground into non functioning workers. I've spent decades on the Psychotherapy end of the re-assembly line which for me was both highly rewarding (no not money) and maidenly suffocating. The correlation between high levels of and long term unemployment and chronic painkiller usage is not surprising to me, but I think the problem starts with people being labeled addicts right off the bat, when 'pain management' is all the rage in the managed care industry. Our medical industry focuses more on treating symptoms than on the curing or remission of medical and mental health conditions. I work in disability law. Insurance companies are fine approving medications, but more expensive treatments or surgery that could provide long term improvements are frequently denied. To make matters worse when people lose their jobs, they often lose insurance coverage and in some states an individual can only quality for medicaid if they have been found disabled. And there is a lot medicaid does not cover. SS does not like to find men or women who are under retirement age disabled, esp under the age of 50.

But we have a huge problem in our country. Many men bet the ages of say 35 and 50 who have only done low or unskilled manual labor their entire working lives who can no longer physically perform this work and cannot easily be retrained for higher skilled, sedentary work. There are also too many men and women being forced out of higher skilled jobs starting in their 40's because of age and wage discrimination. Employers can get 2 recent grads for the price of one senior employees salary.

It is customary on all U.S. Army posts in the U.S. and around the world that I served at, to stop yourself or car and get out, stand at attention, salute or hold your hand over your heart during “Retreat”, the lowering of the American flag on the post.  Even spouses and the military kids did this.  This was considered a sign of respect for the American flag representing their fellow countrymen.   When my brother was killed in Vietnam, Army soldiers presented his coffin at the airport to his wife and my Dad, a former WWII Navy pilot.  His coffin was neatly draped with the U.S. flag.  Out of honor for my brother, the Army soldiers were very respectful of his coffin and the flag covering it.  Since that time, I have had conversations with his fellow pilot and friend who brought his body back to Wisconsin.  I asked him if he and my brother ever talked about the causes, affects, and deeper meanings of war, and more specifically, the Vietnam War.  He told me that my brother was a wonderful guy and trusted friend, and that if Tom would have survived Vietnam as he did, my brother would have been the President of the Vietnam Veteran’s against the war.  My brother died for his country, but he respected others’ lives and struggles, even "enemy" soldiers.  I believe my brother today would fight for and respect the right of his fellow Americans to protest injustices in a respectful manner.  (Thomas F. Shaw, 1972 Panel, 6th row from the top, Vietnam Memorial, Washington D.C. )
